title: Takehome 1
text:
Myanmar, formerly known as Burma, is a country in Southeast Asia with a rich cultural heritage and a complex, often troubled modern history. With a population of about 54 million people and over 135 distinct ethnic groups, Myanmar is a tapestry of diverse cultures, languages, and traditions. However, this diversity has also been a source of long-standing tensions and conflicts.


Since gaining independence from British rule in 1948, Myanmar was under military rule, which ended officially in 2011. However, in February 2021, the military seized power again in a coup, leading to a resumption of armed conflict and violence in the country.
This geospatial analysis of armed conflict in Myanmar aims to:
1. Identify patterns and hotspots of conflict,
2. Examine how they factors interact with each other,
3. Track changes in conflict patterns over time.



This exercise uses the R packages sf, raster, spatstat, tmap, tidyverse, maptools, sp, sparr, st, and ggplot2.

install.packages("maptools", repos = "https://packagemanager.posit.co/cran/2023-10-13")

The following datasets will be used:

Armed Conflict Location and Event Data (ACLED)
Myanmar Information Management Unit (MIMU)

read_csv from readr and st_as_sf from sf from saves the data into a sf object, and st_transform does projection transformation to the proper correct coordinate system:

acled_sf <- read_csv("data/2021-01-01-2024-06-30-Myanmar.csv") %>%
  st_as_sf(coords = c("longitude", "latitude"),
           crs = 4326) %>%
  st_transform(crs = 32647) %>%
  mutate(event_date = dmy(event_date))

chr (20): event_id_cnty, event_date, disorder_type, event_type, sub_event_ty...

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.


Mutate by quarters:

acled_sf <- acled_sf %>%
  mutate(quarter = quarter(event_date))

Plotting out all political violence events by year:

tmap_mode("plot")

tmap mode set to plotting

plots <- list()

for (year_val in 2021:2024) {
  p <- acled_sf %>%
    filter(year == year_val | event_type == "Political violence") %>%
    tm_shape() +
    tm_dots() +
    tm_layout(
      title = paste0("Year: ", year_val),
      title.position = c("left", "bottom"),  
      title.size = 0.8
    )
  
  # Add each plot to the list
  plots[[paste0("plot_", year_val)]] <- p
}

# Arrange the plots in a 2x2 grid
tmap_arrange(plots$plot_2021, plots$plot_2022, plots$plot_2023, plots$plot_2024, nrow = 2, ncol = 2)

Import the myanmar border shapefile as a polygon feature dataframe using st_read from sf:

myanmar_sf <- st_read(dsn = "data/mmr_polbnda_adm0_250k_mimu_1", 
                layer = "mmr_polbnda_adm0_250k_mimu_1") %>%
  st_as_sf(coords =c(
    "longitude", "latitude"),
           crs = 4326) %>%
  st_transform(crs = 32647)

Create a simple plot of the Myanmar border:

tm_shape(myanmar_sf) +
  tm_borders(col = "green", lwd = 2) +
  tm_fill(col = "lightblue", alpha = 0.5) +
  tm_layout(title = "Myanmar Border",
            title.size = 1.2,
            title.position = c("center", "top"))








Filter ACLED data for the specified date range and event types

event_types <- c("Battles", "Explosions/Remote violence", "Strategic developments", "Violence against civilians")
acled_filtered <- acled_sf %>%
  filter(event_type %in% event_types)
summary(acled_filtered)

Create the quarter column:

acled_filtered$Quarter <- paste0(year(acled_filtered$event_date), "_Q", quarter(acled_filtered$event_date))

acled_filtered$QuarterNumeric <- (year(acled_filtered$event_date) - 2021) * 4 + quarter(acled_filtered$event_date)

acled_quarter <- st_sf(
  QuarterNumeric = acled_filtered$QuarterNumeric,
  geometry = st_geometry(acled_filtered), 
  admin1 = acled_filtered$admin1
)

quarters_list <- list()

unique_quarters <- unique(acled_filtered$QuarterNumeric)

for (q in unique_quarters) {
  acled_q <- acled_filtered[acled_filtered$QuarterNumeric == q, ]
  
  acled_q_sf <- st_sf(
    QuarterNumeric = acled_q$QuarterNumeric,
    geometry = st_geometry(acled_q)
  )
  t
  quarters_list[[paste0("Quarter_", q)]] <- acled_q_sf
}


ppp_list <- list()

for (i in names(quarters_list)) {
  q_sf <- quarters_list[[i]]
  
  q_ppp <- as.ppp(st_coordinates(q_sf), st_bbox(q_sf))
  
  ppp_list[[i]] <- q_ppp
}

jittered_ppp_list <- list()

Rescale to kilometers:

armedconflict_ppp_km_list <- list()

for (i in names(armedconflict_ppp_list)){
  armedconflict_ppp_km <- rescale.ppp(armedconflict_ppp_list[[i]], 1000, "km")
  
  armedconflict_ppp_km_list[[i]] <- armedconflict_ppp_km
}

plot_stkde_quarters <- function(start_quarter) {
  quarters <- start_quarter:(start_quarter + 3)
  par(mfrow=c(2,2), mar=c(2,2,2,1))  # Set the layout to 2x2 grid
  
  for(i in quarters) {
    plot(st_kde, i, 
         override.par=FALSE, 
         fix.range=TRUE, 
         main=paste("STKDE Q", i, "(", floor((i-1)/4 + 2021), "Q", (i-1)%% 4 + 1, ")"),
         ribbon=TRUE)  # Ribbon remains on for informative plots
  }
  
}


#just to plot the last 2 
plot_stkde_quarters2 <- function(start_quarter) {
  quarters <- start_quarter:(start_quarter + 1)  # Adjusted to plot 4 quarters
  par(mfrow=c(1,2), mar=c(2,2,2,1))  
  
  for(i in quarters) {
    plot(st_kde, i, 
         override.par=FALSE, 
         fix.range=TRUE, 
         main=paste("STKDE Q", i, "(", floor((i-1)/4 + 2021), "Q", (i-1)%% 4 + 1, ")"),
         ribbon=TRUE)  # Ribbon remains on for informative plots
  }
  
}

A few observations become apparent:

Areas with heavy conflict are the same areas with high population density(Mandalay/Yangon),
Conflict incidence rate picked up around 2021 Q4,
A small spike in fighting occurred in Shan state, near the border with China during the end of 2023,
Huge increase in armed engagements in 2024 Q2 after a lull at the start of the year, especially in Rakhine(West) and Kayin/Mon(Southeast) states.

Whats the reason behind the large increase in conflicts during 2024? Only god knows — until i google use geospatial analysis to find out haha :]

After researching into the reasons behind the conflicts in Myanmar, a few key actors have become apparent to me:

The Tatmadaw (Myanman Military), who started the coup in Febuary 2021,
The Three Brotherhood Alliance(TBA), consisting of the Arakan Army(AA), Myanmar National Democratic Alliance Army(MDNAA), and the Ta’ang National Liberation Army(TNLA) formed in June 2019,
The Karen National Union(KNU), and by extent its armed force the Karen National Liberation Army(KNLA), a group that represents the Karen minority in Myanmar, who have been in conflict with the Myanmar government since 1949.

The bulk of the fighting in the central regions of Myanmar can be attributed to clashes between the Three Brotherhood Alliance and the Tatmadaw, after the TBA voiced opposition to the Tatmadaw on March 29, 2021. Specifically in Rakhine, the AA used the first peace in years to gain control over most of Rakhine state, declaring in August that they controlled over two-thirds of the state.
The big spike in action in late 2023 is caused by Operation 1027, a massive offensive in northern Shan state on October 27, 2023.
Down south in Kayin, tensions between the KNU and the Tatmadaw increased following the coup, leading to hostilities and conflict.

title: Takehome 1
text:
Since gaining independence from British rule in 1948, Myanmar was under military rule, which ended officially in 2011. However, in February 2021, the military seized power again in a coup, leading to a resumption of armed conflict and violence in the country.
This geospatial analysis of armed conflict in Myanmar aims to:
1. Identify patterns and hotspots of conflict,
2. Examine how they factors interact with each other,
3. Track changes in conflict patterns over time.

title: Takehome 1

The following datasets will be used:

Armed Conflict Location and Event Data (ACLED)
Myanmar Information Management Unit (MIMU)

read_csv from readr and st_as_sf from sf from saves the data into a sf object, and st_transform does projection transformation to the proper correct coordinate system:

acled_sf <- read_csv("data/2021-01-01-2024-06-30-Myanmar.csv") %>%
  st_as_sf(coords = c("longitude", "latitude"),
           crs = 4326) %>%
  st_transform(crs = 32647) %>%
  mutate(event_date = dmy(event_date))

Plotting out all political violence events by year:

tmap_mode("plot")

tmap mode set to plotting

plots <- list()

for (year_val in 2021:2024) {
  p <- acled_sf %>%
    filter(year == year_val | event_type == "Political violence") %>%
    tm_shape() +
    tm_dots() +
    tm_layout(
      title = paste0("Year: ", year_val),
      title.position = c("left", "bottom"),  
      title.size = 0.8
    )
  
  # Add each plot to the list
  plots[[paste0("plot_", year_val)]] <- p
}

# Arrange the plots in a 2x2 grid
tmap_arrange(plots$plot_2021, plots$plot_2022, plots$plot_2023, plots$plot_2024, nrow = 2, ncol = 2)

Plotting STKDE:

st_kde <- spattemp.density(ac_ppp)

  Density range: [1.530449e-24, 1.421689e-10]



plot_stkde_quarters <- function(start_quarter) {
  quarters <- start_quarter:(start_quarter + 3)
  par(mfrow=c(2,2), mar=c(2,2,2,1))  # Set the layout to 2x2 grid
  
  for(i in quarters) {
    plot(st_kde, i, 
         override.par=FALSE, 
         fix.range=TRUE, 
         main=paste("STKDE Q", i, "(", floor((i-1)/4 + 2021), "Q", (i-1)%% 4 + 1, ")"),
         ribbon=TRUE)  # Ribbon remains on for informative plots
  }
  
}


#just to plot the last 2 
plot_stkde_quarters2 <- function(start_quarter) {
  quarters <- start_quarter:(start_quarter + 1)  # Adjusted to plot 4 quarters
  par(mfrow=c(1,2), mar=c(2,2,2,1))  
  
  for(i in quarters) {
    plot(st_kde, i, 
         override.par=FALSE, 
         fix.range=TRUE, 
         main=paste("STKDE Q", i, "(", floor((i-1)/4 + 2021), "Q", (i-1)%% 4 + 1, ")"),
         ribbon=TRUE)  # Ribbon remains on for informative plots
  }
  
}


plot_stkde_quarters(1)









plot_stkde_quarters(5)









plot_stkde_quarters(9)









plot_stkde_quarters2(13)








A few observations become apparent:

Areas with heavy conflict are the same areas with high population density(Mandalay/Yangon),
Conflict incidence rate picked up around 2021 Q4,
A small spike in fighting occurred in Shan state, near the border with China during the end of 2023,
Huge increase in armed engagements in 2024 Q2 after a lull at the start of the year, especially in Rakhine(West) and Kayin/Mon(Southeast) states.

Whats the reason behind the large increase in conflicts during 2024? Only god knows — until i google use geospatial analysis to find out haha :]

Creating window for ppp object:

reg_owin <- as.owin(reg_sf)


armedconflictreg_ppp <- acled_jit[reg_owin]


armedconflictreg_sf <- st_as_sf(as.data.frame(acled_jit), coords = c("x", "y"), crs = st_crs(reg_sf))


ggplot() +
  geom_sf(data = reg_sf, aes(fill = ST), alpha = 0.5) +
  geom_sf(data = armedconflictreg_sf, color = "red", size = 0.5, alpha = 0.6) +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(title = "Armed Conflicts in Myanmar",
       fill = "State/Region") +
  theme(legend.position = "bottom")








In the words of former chess world champion vladimir kramnik, “let us begin the procedure”
Comparing between q1 and q14, it is evident that there is significantly increased activity in Rakhine, as well as the areas east of Yangon.

title: Takehome 1
text:
After researching into the reasons behind the conflicts in Myanmar, a few key actors have become apparent to me:

The Tatmadaw (Myanman Military), who started the coup in Febuary 2021,
The Three Brotherhood Alliance(TBA), consisting of the Arakan Army(AA), Myanmar National Democratic Alliance Army(MDNAA), and the Ta’ang National Liberation Army(TNLA) formed in June 2019,
The Karen National Union(KNU), and by extent its armed force the Karen National Liberation Army(KNLA), a group that represents the Karen minority in Myanmar, who have been in conflict with the Myanmar government since 1949.

The bulk of the fighting in the central regions of Myanmar can be attributed to clashes between the Three Brotherhood Alliance and the Tatmadaw, after the TBA voiced opposition to the Tatmadaw on March 29, 2021. Specifically in Rakhine, the AA used the first peace in years to gain control over most of Rakhine state, declaring in August that they controlled over two-thirds of the state.
The big spike in action in late 2023 is caused by Operation 1027, a massive offensive in northern Shan state on October 27, 2023.
Down south in Kayin, tensions between the KNU and the Tatmadaw increased following the coup, leading to hostilities and conflict.

title: ICE 4
text:
#SpatioTemporalPointPatternAnalysis
A spatio-temporal point process is a random collection of points, where each point represents the time and location of an event.

This exercise uses the R packages sf, spdep, tmap, tidyverse.

pacman::p_load(sf, spdep, tmap, tidyverse, knitr)

title: Ex5

basemap <- tm_shape(hunan) +

tmap_arrange(basemap, gdppc, asp=1, ncol=2)

The data above reveals 88 area units in Hunan. THe most connected area unit has 11 neighbors, whilst there are 2 area units with only a single neighbour.

This method shows that within the 88 counties, the most connected area unit has 10 neighbors, whilst there are 2 area units with only a single neighbour.
Visualise contiguity weights:

longitude <- map_dbl(hunan$geometry, ~st_centroid(.x)[[1]])
latitude <- map_dbl(hunan$geometry, ~st_centroid(.x)[[2]])

coords <- cbind(longitude, latitude)

Plot a comparison between Queen and Rook based Neighbours Map:

par(mfrow=c(1,2))
plot(hunan$geometry, border="lightgrey", main="Queen Contiguity")
plot(wm_q, coords, pch = 19, cex = 0.6, add = TRUE, col= "red")
plot(hunan$geometry, border="lightgrey", main="Rook Contiguity")
plot(wm_r, coords, pch = 19, cex = 0.6, add = TRUE, col = "red")

title: Ex5
text:
dnearneigh() identifies the neighbors of region points by Euclidean distance with a distance band with lower d1= and upper d2= bounds controlled by the bounds= argument. If the unprojected coordinates are used and either specified in the coordinates object x or with x as a two column matrix and longlat=TRUE, great circle distances in km will be calculated assuming the WGS84 reference ellipsoid.
Determine the upper limit for distance by:

Getting a matrix of the indices of points from the set of the k-nearest neighbors,
Convert the matrix into a neighbors list of nb class,
Use nbdists to get the length of neighbor relationship edges. If projected, return coordinate pairs, else km,
Remove the list structure using unlist


k1 <- knn2nb(knearneigh(coords))
k1dists <- unlist(nbdists(k1, coords, longlat = TRUE))
summary(k1dists)

   Min. 1st Qu.  Median    Mean 3rd Qu.    Max. 
  24.79   32.57   38.01   39.07   44.52   61.79 


Compute fixed distance weight matrix

wm_d62 <- dnearneigh(coords, 0, 62, longlat = TRUE)
wm_d62

Plot fixed distance weight matrix:

plot(hunan$geometry, border="lightgrey")
plot(wm_d62, coords, add=TRUE)
plot(k1, coords, add=TRUE, col="red", length=0.08)








The red lines show the links of 1st nearest neighbors and the black lines show the links of neighbors within the cut-off distance of 62km.
Splitting the plots for clarity:

par(mfrow=c(1,2))
plot(hunan$geometry, border="lightgrey", main="1st nearest neighbours")
plot(k1, coords, add=TRUE, col="red", length=0.08)
plot(hunan$geometry, border="lightgrey", main="Distance link")
plot(wm_d62, coords, add=TRUE, pch = 19, cex = 0.6)








One characteristic of fixed distance weight matrix is that settlement density and neighbor count are positively correlated. Having many neighbors smoothes the neighbor relationship across more neighbors.
It is possible to control the number of neighbors directly using k-nearest neighbors, either by accepting asymmetric neighbors or imposing symmetry as shown below:

knn6 <- knn2nb(knearneigh(coords, k = 6))

Spatial lag can be calculated as a sum of neighboring values by assigning binary weights. Assign a value of 1 per neighbor:

b_weights <- lapply(wm_q, function(x) 0*x + 1)
b_weights2 <- nb2listw(wm_q, 
                       glist = b_weights, 
                       style = "B")
b_weights2

title: Exercise 3
text:
Spatial Point Pattern Analysis is the evaluation of the distribution of a set of points on a surface. THe points can represent the location of events (crime occurences, accidents), or physical facilities (FnB outlets, healthcare clinics).
This exercise uses spatstat functions to discover the spatial point processes of childcare centers in Singapore, and seeks to answer the following:

Are childcare centers in Singapore randomly distributed throughout the country?
If not, where are the locations with a higher concentration of childcare centers?



This exercise uses the R packages tmap, sf, tidyverse, raster, and spatstat.

install.packages("maptools", repos = "https://packagemanager.posit.co/cran/2023-10-13")

Installing package into 'C:/Users/pwnyt/AppData/Local/R/win-library/4.4'
(as 'lib' is unspecified)


package 'maptools' successfully unpacked and MD5 sums checked

The downloaded binary packages are in
    C:\Users\pwnyt\AppData\Local\Temp\Rtmpmm3M3E\downloaded_packages



pacman::p_load(tmap, sf, tidyverse, raster, spatstat, maptools, sp)




Download the following:

Childcare Services (GeoJSON)
Master Plan 2014 Subzone Boundary Data
CostalOutline from SLA

Using st_read(), import the following geospatial data into R:

childcare_sf<- st_read("data/child-care-services-geojson.geojson") %>% st_transform( crs = 3414) 

Reading layer `child-care-services-geojson' from data source 
  `C:\Users\pwnyt\Documents\GitHub\415\HOE\ex3\data\child-care-services-geojson.geojson' 
  using driver `GeoJSON'
Simple feature collection with 1545 features and 2 fields
Geometry type: POINT
Dimension:     XYZ
Bounding box:  xmin: 103.6824 ymin: 1.248403 xmax: 103.9897 ymax: 1.462134
z_range:       zmin: 0 zmax: 0
Geodetic CRS:  WGS 84



mpsz_sf <- st_read(dsn = "data", layer = "MP14_SUBZONE_WEB_PL")

Reading layer `MP14_SUBZONE_WEB_PL' from data source 
  `C:\Users\pwnyt\Documents\GitHub\415\HOE\ex3\data' using driver `ESRI Shapefile'
Simple feature collection with 323 features and 15 fields
Geometry type: MULTIPOLYGON
Dimension:     XY
Bounding box:  xmin: 2667.538 ymin: 15748.72 xmax: 56396.44 ymax: 50256.33
Projected CRS: SVY21



sg_sf <- st_read(dsn = "data", layer = "CostalOutline")

Reading layer `CostalOutline' from data source 
  `C:\Users\pwnyt\Documents\GitHub\415\HOE\ex3\data' using driver `ESRI Shapefile'
Simple feature collection with 60 features and 4 fields
Geometry type: POLYGON
Dimension:     XY
Bounding box:  xmin: 2663.926 ymin: 16357.98 xmax: 56047.79 ymax: 50244.03
Projected CRS: SVY21


Next, we need to project the dataframes in the same projection system.

mpsz_sf <- st_transform(mpsz_sf, crs = 3414)
sg_sf <- st_transform(sg_sf, crs = 3414)
# childcare_sf is already in EPSG3414

Plot the datasets to observe the spatial patterns.

tm_shape(sg_sf) + tm_polygons() + tm_shape(mpsz_sf) + tm_polygons() + tm_shape(childcare_sf) + tm_dots()








Create an alternative interactive pin map using the code below:

#tmap_mode('view')
#tm_shape(childcare_sf)+
  #tm_dots()


tmap_mode('plot')

tmap mode set to plotting


Geospatial Data Wrangling
Convert sf dataframes to sp’s Spatial* class
The code below uses as_Spatial() from the sf package to convert the three geospatial data from a simple dataframe to sp’s Spatial* class.

childcare <- as_Spatial(childcare_sf)
mpsz <- as_Spatial(mpsz_sf)
sg <- as_Spatial(sg_sf)

childcare_ppp1

#cant get this to work, look later

alternatively use the below to convert from sf into ppp format

childcare_ppp <- as.ppp(st_coordinates(childcare_sf), st_bbox(childcare_sf))

Warning: data contain duplicated points


Looking at the data plot and statistics summary of the ppp object, we can see that both methods result in identical results.

plot(childcare_ppp)









summary(childcare_ppp)

Average intensity 1.91145e-06 points per square unit

Planar point pattern:  1545 points

                    (34200 x 23630 units)
Window area = 808287000 square units


Notice that a warning about duplicates occurs. In spatial point patterns analysis, a significant issue is the presence of duplicates. The statistical methodology used for spatial points patterns processes is based largely on the assumption that processes are simple, that the points cannot be coincident. balls test
The code below can check the duplication in ppp:

any(duplicated(childcare_ppp))

[1] TRUE

multiplicity(childcare_ppp)

To know the number of locations that have more than one point event, run the code below:

sum(multiplicity(childcare_ppp) > 1)

[1] 128


The code below plots out the locations of the duplicate point events:

#tmap_mode('view')
#tm_shape(childcare) + 
#  tm_dots(alpha = 0.3, size = 0.05)
#tmap_mode('plot')

To tackle this problem, use jittering to slightly shift the duplicate points such that they no longer occur at the same point, to make them unique.

childcare_ppp <- rjitter(childcare_ppp, retry = TRUE, nsimm = 1, drop = TRUE)
any(duplicated(childcare_ppp))

[1] FALSE


When analysing spatial point patterns, owin can be used to define a geographic boundary to confine our analysis

sg_owin <- as.owin(sg_sf)
plot(sg_owin)

Fraction of frame area: 0.401



plot(childcareSG_ppp)











The density() function from spatstat computes a kernal density for a given set of point events. The diggle argument can be used to automatically select a bandwidth for computing the kernel density.

kde_childcareSG_bw <- density(childcareSG_ppp, sigma = bw.diggle, edge = TRUE, kernel = "gaussian")
plot(kde_childcareSG_bw)








The density values of the plot above are too low, and make it hard to interpret.

bw <- bw.diggle(childcareSG_ppp)
bw

   sigma 
290.1203 


Rescale the KDE Layers to convert the unit of measurement from m to km.

childcareSG_ppp_km <- rescale(childcareSG_ppp, 1000, "km")
kde_childcareSG_bw <- density(childcareSG_ppp_km, sigma = bw.diggle, edge = TRUE, kernel = "gaussian")
plot(kde_childcareSG_bw)








The resultant plot is much more legible.
Multiple bandwidth calculation methods are available from spatstat, some of which are covered below: Cronie and van Lieshout

bw.CvL(childcareSG_ppp_km)

   sigma 
4.664967 



kde_childcareSG_bw_CvL <- density(childcareSG_ppp_km, sigma =  bw.CvL, edge = TRUE, kernel = "gaussian")

Scott’s Rule

bw.scott(childcareSG_ppp_km)

 sigma.x  sigma.y 
2.224705 1.451138 



kde_childcareSG_bw_scott <- density(childcareSG_ppp_km, sigma =  bw.scott, edge = TRUE, kernel = "gaussian")

Likelihood Cross Validation

bw.ppl(childcareSG_ppp_km)

    sigma 
0.4145034 



kde_childcareSG_bw_ppl <- density(childcareSG_ppp_km, sigma =  bw.ppl, edge = TRUE, kernel = "gaussian")

The plot below compares the above 3 methods with diggle

par(mfrow=c(2,2))
par(mar = c(3,2,2,1))
plot(kde_childcareSG_bw, main = "bw.diggle")
plot(kde_childcareSG_bw_CvL, main = "bw.CvL")
plot(kde_childcareSG_bw_scott, main = "bw.scott")
plot(kde_childcareSG_bw_ppl, main = "bw.ppl")








Different smoothing methods are also available.

par(mfrow = c(2,2))
par(mar = c(3,2,2,1))
plot(density(childcareSG_ppp_km, sigma = bw.ppl, edge = TRUE, kernel = "gaussian"), main = "Gaussian")
plot(density(childcareSG_ppp_km, sigma = bw.ppl, edge = TRUE, kernel = "epanechnikov"), main = "Epanechnikov")

Warning in density.ppp(childcareSG_ppp_km, sigma = bw.ppl, edge = TRUE, :
Bandwidth selection will be based on Gaussian kernel

plot(density(childcareSG_ppp_km, sigma = bw.ppl, edge = TRUE, kernel = "quartic"), main = "Quartic")

Warning in density.ppp(childcareSG_ppp_km, sigma = bw.ppl, edge = TRUE, :
Bandwidth selection will be based on Gaussian kernel

plot(density(childcareSG_ppp_km, sigma = bw.ppl, edge = TRUE, kernel = "disc"), main = "Disc")

Warning in density.ppp(childcareSG_ppp_km, sigma = bw.ppl, edge = TRUE, :
Bandwidth selection will be based on Gaussian kernel









Fixed Bandwidth In the code below, sigma is assigned a value of 0.6, whcih represents 0.6km.

kde_childcareSG_600 <- density(childcareSG_ppp_km, sigma = 0.6, edge = TRUE, kernel = "gaussian")

A fixed bandwidth is sensitive to highly skewed distributions of spatial points, which can be alleviated by using an adaptive bandwidth.

kde_childcareSG_adapt <- adaptive.density(childcareSG_ppp_km, method = "kernel")

Comparing the two:

par(mfrow = c(1,2))
par(mar = c(3,2,2,1))
plot(kde_childcareSG_600)
plot(kde_childcareSG_adapt)








The conversion of a KDE output into a grid object can be done to make it compatible with mapping applications.

gridded_kde_childcareSG_bw <- as.SpatialGridDataFrame.im(kde_childcareSG_bw)
spplot(gridded_kde_childcareSG_bw)








This gridded KDE object can be further converted into a raster layer.

kde_childcareSG_bw_raster <- raster(gridded_kde_childcareSG_bw)
kde_childcareSG_bw_raster

class      : RasterLayer 
dimensions : 128, 128, 16384  (nrow, ncol, ncell)
resolution : 0.4170614, 0.2647348  (x, y)
extent     : 2.663926, 56.04779, 16.35798, 50.24403  (xmin, xmax, ymin, ymax)
crs        : NA 
source     : memory
names      : v 
values     : -9.734652e-15, 29.06721  (min, max)


Set the CRS:

projection(kde_childcareSG_bw_raster) <- CRS("+init=EPSG:3414")
kde_childcareSG_bw_raster

class      : RasterLayer 
dimensions : 128, 128, 16384  (nrow, ncol, ncell)
resolution : 0.4170614, 0.2647348  (x, y)
extent     : 2.663926, 56.04779, 16.35798, 50.24403  (xmin, xmax, ymin, ymax)
crs        : +proj=tmerc +lat_0=1.36666666666667 +lon_0=103.833333333333 +k=1 +x_0=28001.642 +y_0=38744.572 +ellps=WGS84 +units=m +no_defs 
source     : memory
names      : v 
values     : -9.734652e-15, 29.06721  (min, max)


Display the KDE raster layer:

tm_shape(kde_childcareSG_bw_raster) + 
  tm_raster("v", palette="plasma") +
  tm_layout(legend.position = c("right", "bottom"), frame = FALSE)








THe code below extracts the targeted planning areas:

pg <- mpsz_sf %>% filter(PLN_AREA_N == "PUNGGOL")
tm <- mpsz_sf %>% filter(PLN_AREA_N == "TAMPINES")
ck <- mpsz_sf %>% filter(PLN_AREA_N == "CHOA CHU KANG")
jw <- mpsz_sf %>% filter(PLN_AREA_N == "JURONG WEST")


par(mfrow=c(2,2))
par(mar = c(3,2,2,1))
plot(st_geometry(pg), main = "Punggol")
plot(st_geometry(tm), main = "Tampines")
plot(st_geometry(ck), main = "Choa Chu Kang")
plot(st_geometry(jw), main = "Jurong West")









par(mfrow=c(2,2))
par(mar = c(3,2,2,1))
plot(pg, main = "Punggol")

Warning: plotting the first 9 out of 15 attributes; use max.plot = 15 to plot
all










plot(tm, main = "Tampines")

Warning: plotting the first 9 out of 15 attributes; use max.plot = 15 to plot
all










plot(ck, main = "Choa Chu Kang")

Warning: plotting the first 10 out of 15 attributes; use max.plot = 15 to plot
all










plot(jw, main = "Jurong West")

Warning: plotting the first 9 out of 15 attributes; use max.plot = 15 to plot
all









Convert these SpatialPolygon objects into owin objects:

pg_owin <- as.owin(pg)
tm_owin <- as.owin(tm)
ck_owin <- as.owin(ck)
jw_owin <- as.owin(jw)

Extract the childcare centre points within each of the study planning areas:

childcare_pg_ppp = childcare_ppp[pg_owin]
childcare_tm_ppp = childcare_ppp[tm_owin]
childcare_ck_ppp = childcare_ppp[ck_owin]
childcare_jw_ppp = childcare_ppp[jw_owin]

Rescale from m to km:

childcare_pg_ppp.km = rescale(childcare_pg_ppp, 1000, "km")
childcare_tm_ppp.km = rescale(childcare_tm_ppp, 1000, "km")
childcare_ck_ppp.km = rescale(childcare_ck_ppp, 1000, "km")
childcare_jw_ppp.km = rescale(childcare_jw_ppp, 1000, "km")

Plot out the individual areas overlaid with their childcare centres:

par(mfrow=c(2,2))
par(mar = c(3,2,2,1))
plot(childcare_pg_ppp.km, main="Punggol")
plot(childcare_tm_ppp.km, main="Tampines")
plot(childcare_ck_ppp.km, main="Choa Chu Kang")
plot(childcare_jw_ppp.km, main="Jurong West")








Compute the KDE, using diggle to derive the bandwidth:

par(mfrow = c(2,2))
par(mar = c(3,2,2,1))
plot(density(childcare_pg_ppp.km, 
             sigma=bw.diggle, 
             edge=TRUE, 
             kernel="gaussian"),
     main="Punggol")
plot(density(childcare_tm_ppp.km, 
             sigma=bw.diggle, 
             edge=TRUE, 
             kernel="gaussian"),
     main="Tempines")
plot(density(childcare_ck_ppp.km, 
             sigma=bw.diggle, 
             edge=TRUE, 
             kernel="gaussian"),
     main="Choa Chu Kang")
plot(density(childcare_jw_ppp.km, 
             sigma=bw.diggle, 
             edge=TRUE, 
             kernel="gaussian"),
     main="Jurong West")








Compute the KDE using a fixed bandwidth of 0.25km:

par(mfrow=c(2,2))
par(mar = c(3,2,2,1))
plot(density(childcare_ck_ppp.km, 
             sigma=0.25, 
             edge=TRUE, 
             kernel="gaussian"),
     main="Chou Chu Kang")
plot(density(childcare_jw_ppp.km, 
             sigma=0.25, 
             edge=TRUE, 
             kernel="gaussian"),
     main="JUrong West")
plot(density(childcare_pg_ppp.km, 
             sigma=0.25, 
             edge=TRUE, 
             kernel="gaussian"),
     main="Punggol")
plot(density(childcare_tm_ppp.km, 
             sigma=0.25, 
             edge=TRUE, 
             kernel="gaussian"),
     main="Tampines")











Perform the Clark-Evans test of aggregation:

H0: Random distribution of childcare centres
H1: Non-Random distribution of childcare centres


clarkevans.test(childcareSG_ppp, correction = "none", clipregion = "sg_owin", alternative = c("clustered"), nsim = 99)


    Clark-Evans test
    No edge correction
    Z-test

data:  childcareSG_ppp
R = 0.56222, p-value < 2.2e-16
alternative hypothesis: clustered (R < 1)


The R value from the above result indicates clustering, and as p < 0.05, H0 can be rejected.
Performing the same test on the target planning areas:
Tampines

clarkevans.test(childcare_tm_ppp, correction = "none", clipregion = "sg_owin", alternative = c("clustered"), nsim = 99)


    Clark-Evans test
    No edge correction
    Z-test

data:  childcare_tm_ppp
R = 0.7738, p-value = 2.228e-05
alternative hypothesis: clustered (R < 1)


The R value from the above result indicates clustering, and as p < 0.05, H0 can be rejected.
Choa Chu Kang

clarkevans.test(childcare_ck_ppp, correction = "none", clipregion = "sg_owin", alternative = c("clustered"), nsim = 99)


    Clark-Evans test
    No edge correction
    Z-test

data:  childcare_ck_ppp
R = 0.93749, p-value = 0.1752
alternative hypothesis: clustered (R < 1)


As p > 0.05, H0 cannot be rejected.
Punggol

clarkevans.test(childcare_pg_ppp, correction = "none", clipregion = "sg_owin", alternative = c("clustered"), nsim = 99)


    Clark-Evans test
    No edge correction
    Z-test

data:  childcare_pg_ppp
R = 0.92455, p-value = 0.1298
alternative hypothesis: clustered (R < 1)


As p < 0.05, H0 can be rejected.
Jurong West

clarkevans.test(childcare_jw_ppp, correction = "none", clipregion = "sg_owin", alternative = c("clustered"), nsim = 99)


    Clark-Evans test
    No edge correction
    Z-test

data:  childcare_jw_ppp
R = 0.92209, p-value = 0.08103
alternative hypothesis: clustered (R < 1)


As p < 0.05, H0 can be rejected.



The G function measures the distribution of the distances from an arbitrary even to its nearest event. G function on the Choa Chu Kang area:

G_CK = Gest(childcare_ck_ppp, correction = "border")
plot(G_CK, xlim=c(0,500))

title: Exercise 3

pacman::p_load(tmap, sf, tidyverse, raster, spatstat, maptools, sp)

title: Exercise 3
text:
Download the following:

Childcare Services (GeoJSON)
Master Plan 2014 Subzone Boundary Data
CostalOutline from SLA

Using st_read(), import the following geospatial data into R:

childcare_sf<- st_read("data/child-care-services-geojson.geojson") %>% st_transform( crs = 3414) 

Reading layer `child-care-services-geojson' from data source 
  `C:\Users\pwnyt\Documents\GitHub\415\HOE\ex3\data\child-care-services-geojson.geojson' 
  using driver `GeoJSON'
Simple feature collection with 1545 features and 2 fields
Geometry type: POINT
Dimension:     XYZ
Bounding box:  xmin: 103.6824 ymin: 1.248403 xmax: 103.9897 ymax: 1.462134
z_range:       zmin: 0 zmax: 0
Geodetic CRS:  WGS 84



mpsz_sf <- st_read(dsn = "data", layer = "MP14_SUBZONE_WEB_PL")

Reading layer `MP14_SUBZONE_WEB_PL' from data source 
  `C:\Users\pwnyt\Documents\GitHub\415\HOE\ex3\data' using driver `ESRI Shapefile'
Simple feature collection with 323 features and 15 fields
Geometry type: MULTIPOLYGON
Dimension:     XY
Bounding box:  xmin: 2667.538 ymin: 15748.72 xmax: 56396.44 ymax: 50256.33
Projected CRS: SVY21



sg_sf <- st_read(dsn = "data", layer = "CostalOutline")

Reading layer `CostalOutline' from data source 
  `C:\Users\pwnyt\Documents\GitHub\415\HOE\ex3\data' using driver `ESRI Shapefile'
Simple feature collection with 60 features and 4 fields
Geometry type: POLYGON
Dimension:     XY
Bounding box:  xmin: 2663.926 ymin: 16357.98 xmax: 56047.79 ymax: 50244.03
Projected CRS: SVY21


Next, we need to project the dataframes in the same projection system.

mpsz_sf <- st_transform(mpsz_sf, crs = 3414)
sg_sf <- st_transform(sg_sf, crs = 3414)
# childcare_sf is already in EPSG3414

Plot the datasets to observe the spatial patterns.

tm_shape(sg_sf) + tm_polygons() + tm_shape(mpsz_sf) + tm_polygons() + tm_shape(childcare_sf) + tm_dots()








Create an alternative interactive pin map using the code below:

#tmap_mode('view')
#tm_shape(childcare_sf)+
  #tm_dots()


tmap_mode('plot')

tmap mode set to plotting


Geospatial Data Wrangling
Convert sf dataframes to sp’s Spatial* class
The code below uses as_Spatial() from the sf package to convert the three geospatial data from a simple dataframe to sp’s Spatial* class.

childcare <- as_Spatial(childcare_sf)
mpsz <- as_Spatial(mpsz_sf)
sg <- as_Spatial(sg_sf)

childcare_sp <- as(childcare, "SpatialPoints")
sg_sp <- as(sg, "SpatialPolygons")

Convert sp format into spatstat’s ppp format

#win <- as.owin(childcare_sp)
childcare_ppp1 <- as(childcare_sp, "ppp")
childcare_ppp1

Planar point pattern: 1545 points
window: rectangle = [11203.01, 45404.24] x [25667.6, 49300.88] units

#cant get this to work, look later

alternatively use the below to convert from sf into ppp format

childcare_ppp <- as.ppp(st_coordinates(childcare_sf), st_bbox(childcare_sf))

Warning: data contain duplicated points


Looking at the data plot and statistics summary of the ppp object, we can see that both methods result in identical results.

plot(childcare_ppp)









summary(childcare_ppp)

Marked planar point pattern:  1545 points
Average intensity 1.91145e-06 points per square unit

*Pattern contains duplicated points*

Coordinates are given to 11 decimal places

marks are numeric, of type 'double'

   Min. 1st Qu.  Median    Mean 3rd Qu.    Max. 
      0       0       0       0       0       0

                    (34200 x 23630 units)
Window area = 808287000 square units



plot(childcare_ppp1)









summary(childcare_ppp1)

Planar point pattern:  1545 points
Average intensity 1.91145e-06 points per square unit

*Pattern contains duplicated points*

Coordinates are given to 11 decimal places

Window: rectangle = [11203.01, 45404.24] x [25667.6, 49300.88] units
                    (34200 x 23630 units)
Window area = 808287000 square units


Notice that a warning about duplicates occurs. In spatial point patterns analysis, a significant issue is the presence of duplicates. The statistical methodology used for spatial points patterns processes is based largely on the assumption that processes are simple, that the points cannot be coincident. balls test
The code below can check the duplication in ppp:

any(duplicated(childcare_ppp))

[1] TRUE


To count the number of coincidence points, the multiplicity() function can be used:

multiplicity(childcare_ppp)

To know the number of locations that have more than one point event, run the code below:

sum(multiplicity(childcare_ppp) > 1)

[1] 128


The code below plots out the locations of the duplicate point events:

#tmap_mode('view')
#tm_shape(childcare) + 
#  tm_dots(alpha = 0.3, size = 0.05)
#tmap_mode('plot')

To tackle this problem, use jittering to slightly shift the duplicate points such that they no longer occur at the same point, to make them unique.

childcare_ppp <- rjitter(childcare_ppp, retry = TRUE, nsimm = 1, drop = TRUE)
any(duplicated(childcare_ppp))

[1] FALSE

title: Exercise 3
text:
The density() function from spatstat computes a kernal density for a given set of point events. The diggle argument can be used to automatically select a bandwidth for computing the kernel density.

kde_childcareSG_bw <- density(childcareSG_ppp, sigma = bw.diggle, edge = TRUE, kernel = "gaussian")
plot(kde_childcareSG_bw)








The density values of the plot above are too low, and make it hard to interpret.

bw <- bw.diggle(childcareSG_ppp)
bw

   sigma 
290.1203 


Rescale the KDE Layers to convert the unit of measurement from m to km.

childcareSG_ppp_km <- rescale(childcareSG_ppp, 1000, "km")
kde_childcareSG_bw <- density(childcareSG_ppp_km, sigma = bw.diggle, edge = TRUE, kernel = "gaussian")
plot(kde_childcareSG_bw)








The resultant plot is much more legible.
Multiple bandwidth calculation methods are available from spatstat, some of which are covered below: Cronie and van Lieshout

bw.CvL(childcareSG_ppp_km)

   sigma 
4.664967 



kde_childcareSG_bw_CvL <- density(childcareSG_ppp_km, sigma =  bw.CvL, edge = TRUE, kernel = "gaussian")

Scott’s Rule

bw.scott(childcareSG_ppp_km)

 sigma.x  sigma.y 
2.224705 1.451138 



kde_childcareSG_bw_scott <- density(childcareSG_ppp_km, sigma =  bw.scott, edge = TRUE, kernel = "gaussian")

Likelihood Cross Validation

bw.ppl(childcareSG_ppp_km)

    sigma 
0.4145034 



kde_childcareSG_bw_ppl <- density(childcareSG_ppp_km, sigma =  bw.ppl, edge = TRUE, kernel = "gaussian")

The plot below compares the above 3 methods with diggle

par(mfrow=c(2,2))
par(mar = c(3,2,2,1))
plot(kde_childcareSG_bw, main = "bw.diggle")
plot(kde_childcareSG_bw_CvL, main = "bw.CvL")
plot(kde_childcareSG_bw_scott, main = "bw.scott")
plot(kde_childcareSG_bw_ppl, main = "bw.ppl")








Different smoothing methods are also available.

par(mfrow = c(2,2))
par(mar = c(3,2,2,1))
plot(density(childcareSG_ppp_km, sigma = bw.ppl, edge = TRUE, kernel = "gaussian"), main = "Gaussian")
plot(density(childcareSG_ppp_km, sigma = bw.ppl, edge = TRUE, kernel = "epanechnikov"), main = "Epanechnikov")

Warning in density.ppp(childcareSG_ppp_km, sigma = bw.ppl, edge = TRUE, :
Bandwidth selection will be based on Gaussian kernel

plot(density(childcareSG_ppp_km, sigma = bw.ppl, edge = TRUE, kernel = "quartic"), main = "Quartic")

Warning in density.ppp(childcareSG_ppp_km, sigma = bw.ppl, edge = TRUE, :
Bandwidth selection will be based on Gaussian kernel

plot(density(childcareSG_ppp_km, sigma = bw.ppl, edge = TRUE, kernel = "disc"), main = "Disc")

Warning in density.ppp(childcareSG_ppp_km, sigma = bw.ppl, edge = TRUE, :
Bandwidth selection will be based on Gaussian kernel









Fixed Bandwidth In the code below, sigma is assigned a value of 0.6, whcih represents 0.6km.

kde_childcareSG_600 <- density(childcareSG_ppp_km, sigma = 0.6, edge = TRUE, kernel = "gaussian")

A fixed bandwidth is sensitive to highly skewed distributions of spatial points, which can be alleviated by using an adaptive bandwidth.

kde_childcareSG_adapt <- adaptive.density(childcareSG_ppp_km, method = "kernel")

Comparing the two:

par(mfrow = c(1,2))
par(mar = c(3,2,2,1))
plot(kde_childcareSG_600)
plot(kde_childcareSG_adapt)








The conversion of a KDE output into a grid object can be done to make it compatible with mapping applications.

gridded_kde_childcareSG_bw <- as.SpatialGridDataFrame.im(kde_childcareSG_bw)
spplot(gridded_kde_childcareSG_bw)








This gridded KDE object can be further converted into a raster layer.

kde_childcareSG_bw_raster <- raster(gridded_kde_childcareSG_bw)
kde_childcareSG_bw_raster

class      : RasterLayer 
dimensions : 128, 128, 16384  (nrow, ncol, ncell)
resolution : 0.4170614, 0.2647348  (x, y)
extent     : 2.663926, 56.04779, 16.35798, 50.24403  (xmin, xmax, ymin, ymax)
crs        : NA 
source     : memory
names      : v 
values     : -9.734652e-15, 29.06721  (min, max)


Set the CRS:

projection(kde_childcareSG_bw_raster) <- CRS("+init=EPSG:3414")
kde_childcareSG_bw_raster

class      : RasterLayer 
dimensions : 128, 128, 16384  (nrow, ncol, ncell)
resolution : 0.4170614, 0.2647348  (x, y)
extent     : 2.663926, 56.04779, 16.35798, 50.24403  (xmin, xmax, ymin, ymax)
crs        : +proj=tmerc +lat_0=1.36666666666667 +lon_0=103.833333333333 +k=1 +x_0=28001.642 +y_0=38744.572 +ellps=WGS84 +units=m +no_defs 
source     : memory
names      : v 
values     : -9.734652e-15, 29.06721  (min, max)


Display the KDE raster layer:

tm_shape(kde_childcareSG_bw_raster) + 
  tm_raster("v", palette="plasma") +
  tm_layout(legend.position = c("right", "bottom"), frame = FALSE)








THe code below extracts the targeted planning areas:

pg <- mpsz_sf %>% filter(PLN_AREA_N == "PUNGGOL")
tm <- mpsz_sf %>% filter(PLN_AREA_N == "TAMPINES")
ck <- mpsz_sf %>% filter(PLN_AREA_N == "CHOA CHU KANG")
jw <- mpsz_sf %>% filter(PLN_AREA_N == "JURONG WEST")


par(mfrow=c(2,2))
par(mar = c(3,2,2,1))
plot(st_geometry(pg), main = "Punggol")
plot(st_geometry(tm), main = "Tampines")
plot(st_geometry(ck), main = "Choa Chu Kang")
plot(st_geometry(jw), main = "Jurong West")









par(mfrow=c(2,2))
par(mar = c(3,2,2,1))
plot(pg, main = "Punggol")

Warning: plotting the first 9 out of 15 attributes; use max.plot = 15 to plot
all










plot(tm, main = "Tampines")

Warning: plotting the first 9 out of 15 attributes; use max.plot = 15 to plot
all










plot(ck, main = "Choa Chu Kang")

Warning: plotting the first 10 out of 15 attributes; use max.plot = 15 to plot
all










plot(jw, main = "Jurong West")

Warning: plotting the first 9 out of 15 attributes; use max.plot = 15 to plot
all









Convert these SpatialPolygon objects into owin objects:

pg_owin <- as.owin(pg)
tm_owin <- as.owin(tm)
ck_owin <- as.owin(ck)
jw_owin <- as.owin(jw)

Extract the childcare centre points within each of the study planning areas:

childcare_pg_ppp = childcare_ppp[pg_owin]
childcare_tm_ppp = childcare_ppp[tm_owin]
childcare_ck_ppp = childcare_ppp[ck_owin]
childcare_jw_ppp = childcare_ppp[jw_owin]

Rescale from m to km:

childcare_pg_ppp.km = rescale(childcare_pg_ppp, 1000, "km")
childcare_tm_ppp.km = rescale(childcare_tm_ppp, 1000, "km")
childcare_ck_ppp.km = rescale(childcare_ck_ppp, 1000, "km")
childcare_jw_ppp.km = rescale(childcare_jw_ppp, 1000, "km")

Plot out the individual areas overlaid with their childcare centres:

par(mfrow=c(2,2))
par(mar = c(3,2,2,1))
plot(childcare_pg_ppp.km, main="Punggol")
plot(childcare_tm_ppp.km, main="Tampines")
plot(childcare_ck_ppp.km, main="Choa Chu Kang")
plot(childcare_jw_ppp.km, main="Jurong West")








Compute the KDE, using diggle to derive the bandwidth:

par(mfrow = c(2,2))
par(mar = c(3,2,2,1))
plot(density(childcare_pg_ppp.km, 
             sigma=bw.diggle, 
             edge=TRUE, 
             kernel="gaussian"),
     main="Punggol")
plot(density(childcare_tm_ppp.km, 
             sigma=bw.diggle, 
             edge=TRUE, 
             kernel="gaussian"),
     main="Tempines")
plot(density(childcare_ck_ppp.km, 
             sigma=bw.diggle, 
             edge=TRUE, 
             kernel="gaussian"),
     main="Choa Chu Kang")
plot(density(childcare_jw_ppp.km, 
             sigma=bw.diggle, 
             edge=TRUE, 
             kernel="gaussian"),
     main="Jurong West")








Compute the KDE using a fixed bandwidth of 0.25km:

par(mfrow=c(2,2))
par(mar = c(3,2,2,1))
plot(density(childcare_ck_ppp.km, 
             sigma=0.25, 
             edge=TRUE, 
             kernel="gaussian"),
     main="Chou Chu Kang")
plot(density(childcare_jw_ppp.km, 
             sigma=0.25, 
             edge=TRUE, 
             kernel="gaussian"),
     main="JUrong West")
plot(density(childcare_pg_ppp.km, 
             sigma=0.25, 
             edge=TRUE, 
             kernel="gaussian"),
     main="Punggol")
plot(density(childcare_tm_ppp.km, 
             sigma=0.25, 
             edge=TRUE, 
             kernel="gaussian"),
     main="Tampines")

title: Exercise 3
text:
Perform the Clark-Evans test of aggregation:

H0: Random distribution of childcare centres
H1: Non-Random distribution of childcare centres


clarkevans.test(childcareSG_ppp, correction = "none", clipregion = "sg_owin", alternative = c("clustered"), nsim = 99)


    Clark-Evans test
    No edge correction
    Z-test

data:  childcareSG_ppp
R = 0.56222, p-value < 2.2e-16
alternative hypothesis: clustered (R < 1)


The R value from the above result indicates clustering, and as p < 0.05, H0 can be rejected.
Performing the same test on the target planning areas:
Tampines

clarkevans.test(childcare_tm_ppp, correction = "none", clipregion = "sg_owin", alternative = c("clustered"), nsim = 99)


    Clark-Evans test
    No edge correction
    Z-test

data:  childcare_tm_ppp
R = 0.7738, p-value = 2.228e-05
alternative hypothesis: clustered (R < 1)


The R value from the above result indicates clustering, and as p < 0.05, H0 can be rejected.
Choa Chu Kang

clarkevans.test(childcare_ck_ppp, correction = "none", clipregion = "sg_owin", alternative = c("clustered"), nsim = 99)


    Clark-Evans test
    No edge correction
    Z-test

data:  childcare_ck_ppp
R = 0.93749, p-value = 0.1752
alternative hypothesis: clustered (R < 1)


As p > 0.05, H0 cannot be rejected.
Punggol

clarkevans.test(childcare_pg_ppp, correction = "none", clipregion = "sg_owin", alternative = c("clustered"), nsim = 99)


    Clark-Evans test
    No edge correction
    Z-test

data:  childcare_pg_ppp
R = 0.92455, p-value = 0.1298
alternative hypothesis: clustered (R < 1)


As p < 0.05, H0 can be rejected.
Jurong West

clarkevans.test(childcare_jw_ppp, correction = "none", clipregion = "sg_owin", alternative = c("clustered"), nsim = 99)


    Clark-Evans test
    No edge correction
    Z-test

data:  childcare_jw_ppp
R = 0.92209, p-value = 0.08103
alternative hypothesis: clustered (R < 1)


As p < 0.05, H0 can be rejected.

title: Exercise 1
text: Getting Started

title: Exercise 1
text:
Install/Launch R Packages
This exercise uses the R packages sf and tidyverse.

sf imports, manages and processes geospatial data
tidyverse wrangles and visualises said data

Use p_load to install the packages into the environment:

pacman::p_load(sf, tidyverse)

title: Exercise 1
text:
Download and Import Data
Download the following:
Pre-Schools Location Data
Master Plan 2014 Subzone Boundary Data
LTA Cycling Path Data
Singapore Airbnb Listing Data
Inside the Ex1 folder, create a subfolder called data, and within that create 2 two more subfolders named geospatial and aspatial respectively.
Using st_read(), import the following geospatial data into R:

mpsz = st_read(dsn = "data/geospatial", layer = "MP14_SUBZONE_WEB_PL")

Reading layer `MP14_SUBZONE_WEB_PL' from data source 
  `C:\Users\pwnyt\Documents\GitHub\415\HOE\ex1\data\geospatial' 
  using driver `ESRI Shapefile'
Simple feature collection with 323 features and 15 fields
Geometry type: MULTIPOLYGON
Dimension:     XY
Bounding box:  xmin: 2667.538 ymin: 15748.72 xmax: 56396.44 ymax: 50256.33
Projected CRS: SVY21


This code uses the st_read() function from sf to import the MP14_SUBZONE_WEB_PL shapefile into R as a polygon feature dataframe. It shows that there are a total of 323 multipolygon features and 15 fields, in the svy21 projected coordinates system.
Next, import the CyclingPathGazette data:

cyclingpath = st_read(dsn = "data/geospatial", layer = "CyclingPathGazette")

Reading layer `CyclingPathGazette' from data source 
  `C:\Users\pwnyt\Documents\GitHub\415\HOE\ex1\data\geospatial' 
  using driver `ESRI Shapefile'
Simple feature collection with 3138 features and 2 fields
Geometry type: MULTILINESTRING
Dimension:     XY
Bounding box:  xmin: 11854.32 ymin: 28347.98 xmax: 42644.17 ymax: 48948.15
Projected CRS: SVY21


This code imports the CyclingPathGazette shapefile into R as a line feature dataframe. It reveals that there are 2558 features and 2 fields, and is similarly in the the svy21 projected coordinates system.
Lastly, import the PreSchoolsLocations data:

preschool = st_read(dsn = "data/geospatial/PreSchoolsLocation.kml")

Reading layer `PRESCHOOLS_LOCATION' from data source 
  `C:\Users\pwnyt\Documents\GitHub\415\HOE\ex1\data\geospatial\PreSchoolsLocation.kml' 
  using driver `KML'
Simple feature collection with 2290 features and 2 fields
Geometry type: POINT
Dimension:     XYZ
Bounding box:  xmin: 103.6878 ymin: 1.247759 xmax: 103.9897 ymax: 1.462134
z_range:       zmin: 0 zmax: 0
Geodetic CRS:  WGS 84


This code indicates that it is in a point feature dataframe, containing 2290 features and 2 fields. It is in the wgs84 coordinates system, contrary to the previous two dataframes.
For the aspatial data, it must first be imported into a tibble dataframe, then converted into a simple feature dataframe.

listings <- read_csv("data/aspatial/listings.csv")

Rows: 3540 Columns: 18
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr   (6): name, host_name, neighbourhood_group, neighbourhood, room_type, l...
dbl  (11): id, host_id, latitude, longitude, price, minimum_nights, number_o...
date  (1): last_review

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.



list(listings)

[[1]]
# A tibble: 3,540 × 18
       id name      host_id host_name neighbourhood_group neighbourhood latitude
    <dbl> <chr>       <dbl> <chr>     <chr>               <chr>            <dbl>
 1  71609 Ensuite …  367042 Belinda   East Region         Tampines          1.35
 2  71896 B&B  Roo…  367042 Belinda   East Region         Tampines          1.35
 3  71903 Room 2-n…  367042 Belinda   East Region         Tampines          1.35
 4 275343 10min wa… 1439258 Kay       Central Region      Bukit Merah       1.29
 5 275344 15 mins … 1439258 Kay       Central Region      Bukit Merah       1.29
 6 289234 Booking …  367042 Belinda   East Region         Tampines          1.34
 7 294281 5 mins w… 1521514 Elizabeth Central Region      Newton            1.31
 8 324945 Comforta… 1439258 Kay       Central Region      Bukit Merah       1.29
 9 330095 Relaxing… 1439258 Kay       Central Region      Bukit Merah       1.29
10 344803 Budget s…  367042 Belinda   East Region         Tampines          1.35
# ℹ 3,530 more rows
# ℹ 11 more variables: longitude <dbl>, room_type <chr>, price <dbl>,
#   minimum_nights <dbl>, number_of_reviews <dbl>, last_review <date>,
#   reviews_per_month <dbl>, calculated_host_listings_count <dbl>,
#   availability_365 <dbl>, number_of_reviews_ltm <dbl>, license <chr>


The output shows that the listings tibble dataframe contains 3450 rows and 18 columns.

listings_sf <- st_as_sf(listings, coords = c("longitude", "latitude"), crs=4326) %>%
  st_transform(crs=3414)

This code converts the listings tibble dataframe into a simple feature dataframe.

coords argument requiresthe column name of the x-coordinates first then followed by the column name of the y-coordinates
crs argument requiresthe coordinates system in epsg format. EPSG: 4326 is wgs84 Geographic Coordinate System, and EPSG: 3414 is Singapore svy21 Projected Coordinate System
%>% is used to nest st_transform() to transform the newly created simple feature dataframe into svy21 projected coordinates system.
